text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Vendex goes ahead with plans to sell stake in fellow retail group KBB despite shar fall in KBB share price. (p1)
- Bank insurer ING Group plans to launch its Postbank subsidiary's home-banking formula in Canada. (p1)
- Unions and employers in printing sector reach agreement on draft collective labour contract including revolutionary decentralised approach to wage-bargaining. (p1)
- Philips Electronics confirms cooperation with Japan's Hosiden in manufacture of liquid crystal displays (LCDs). (p3)
- Royal Dutch/Shell oil group remains a bulwark of integrity despite Brent Spar debacle and alleged support of Nigeria's military regime, says chief executive Cor Herkstroeter. (p3)
- Philips Electronics unit PolyGram stands to lose some $10 million due to delay in release of pop group U2's new CD. (p4)
- South Korean industrial giant Samsung willing to pay 1.5 billion guilders to take over failed aircraft maker Fokker. (p2)
- Rabobank chief says fight among banks over "smart" payment card will cost consumers money. (p2)
- ING Bank will pay Dutch soccer association KNVB full one billion guilder fee for TV soccer rights even if new Sport7 channel, which bought rights in seven-year deal, goes bust. (p3)
- Amsterdam canal cruise operator Lovers, which recently started fledgling rail operation, says it willing to take over more unprofitable lines from state-owned rail company NS. (p1)
- Prime Minister Wim Kok says reduction in highest income-tax rate of 60 percent will only be possible if accompanied by cut in number of tax-deductible expenses. (p3)
- Philips Electronics returns to personal computer market with plan to start selling PCs in Asia. (p13)
- Justice Ministry wants to prevent children from ethnic minorities from drifting into life of crime by advising their parents on how to bring them up. (p1)
